user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_shmem_open_generic:
```c
int metal_shmem_open_generic(const char *name, size_t size,
			     struct metal_io_region **result)
{
	struct metal_generic_shmem *shmem;
	struct metal_list *node;

	metal_list_for_each(&_metal.common.generic_shmem_list, node) {
		shmem = metal_container_of(node, struct metal_generic_shmem, node);
		if (strcmp(shmem->name, name) != 0)
			continue;
		if (size <= metal_io_region_size(&shmem->io)) {
			*result = &shmem->io;
			return 0;
		}
	}

	return -ENOENT;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function metal_shmem_open_generic:
#define metal_list_for_each(list, node) for((node)=(list)->next;(node)!=(list);(node)=(node)->next)
...
#define metal_container_of(ptr, structure, member) (void*)((uintptr_t)(ptr)-metal_offset_of(structure,member))
...
struct metal_list {
	struct metal_list *next, *prev;
}
...
struct metal_generic_shmem {
	const char		*name;
	struct metal_io_region	io;
	struct metal_list	node;
}
...
struct metal_io_region {
	void			*virt;      /**< base virtual address */
	const metal_phys_addr_t	*physmap;   /**< table of base physical address
						 of each of the pages in the I/O
						 region */
	size_t			size;       /**< size of the I/O region */
	unsigned long		page_shift; /**< page shift of I/O region */
	metal_phys_addr_t	page_mask;  /**< page mask of I/O region */
	unsigned int		mem_flags;  /**< memory attribute of the
						 I/O region */
	struct metal_io_ops	ops;        /**< I/O region operations */
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Fragments not listed do not need investigation for Rule 14.2 because they do not affect the for-loop well-formedness: the surrounding declarations (local variable declarations, struct/type definitions, the final return -ENOENT) are unrelated to the for-statement clauses; the loop counter candidate (node) and the list head expression are visible in the reported fragments so any accesses/modifications relevant to the rule are covered; other macros/definitions not shown do not change the for-clause expressions. The only function calls and control-flow statements that can influence whether the loop is well-formed (by introducing side effects on objects used in the for clauses or by modifying the loop counter) appear inside the reported for-loop fragment and should be inspected (strcmp, metal_io_region_size and any functions they call). Other lines in the file do not modify the loop counter or the objects used in the loop clauses and therefore need not be investigated for Rule 14.2.
